conclusion: Analyze spring-mass system to find height A rises and spring constant k₂.
Given: mass of A = 2 kg, spring constant k₁ = 200 N/m, unknown k₂, distance ab = 0.6 m, A initially at rest, tension in B equals gravitational force on A when C is pulled to b.
Initial condition: A is at rest, spring B stretched to support A's weight. Initial stretch x₀ calculated as 9.8 cm.
Final condition: Define h as height A rises, x₁ as new stretch of B. New tension T_B = k₁x₁ equals gravitational force, so x₁ = x₀, stretch of B doesn't change.
Calculate stretch of spring C: s = ab + h = 0.6 m + h.
Force equilibrium in horizontal direction: k₂s = T_rope = k₁x₀ = mg = 19.6 N, so k₂(0.6 + h) = 19.6 N.
Calculate h using geometry: Total rope length constant, spring C extends by h when endpoint moves from a to b.
Calculate k₂: h = 0.6 m, k₂(1.2) = 19.6 N, k₂ = 16.33 N/m.
Final answer: height A rises = 0.6 m, spring constant k₂ = 16.33 N/m.
